SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Cancer stem-like cells (CSCs) in colorectal cancers (CRC) may account for the failure of treatments because they are resistant to many current anticancer therapies
Salinomycin, a potassium ionophore, was recently identified as a selective inhibitor of breast CSCs
METHODS: The human CRC cell lines HT29 and SW480 were treated with salinomycin and oxaliplatin
Cell viability was determined with cell counting kit 8
Fraction of CD133+ cell subpopulations was assessed by Flow Cytometric analysis
Clonogenecity and migration were determined with soft agar and Boyden chamber assays
Molecular changes were assessed by immunofluorescence staining, RT-PCR, and Western blot analysis
RESULTS: We report that salinomycin reduces the proportion of CD133+ subpopulations in human CRC HT29 and SW480 cells
Furthermore, salinomycin treatment decreases colony-forming ability and cell motility in HT29 cells
Moreover, salinomycin downregulates the expression of vimentin and induces the E-cadherin expression in HT29 cells
CONCLUSIONS: This study demonstrates the ability of salinomycin to selectively target "CD133+" cell subpopulations and decrease the malignant traits in colorectal cancer lines
